topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Install the Messaging Broker Service

body.p: This section provides details on installing the Messaging service for the Development Platform.

ul.li: The HDP Installer 2.0, also known as HDPI, must already be installed.
Populate the Messaging section of the clouds.yaml file.
You must know the NTP server and DNS server IP addresses.

ol.li: SSH into the HP Helion OpenStack Deployer. (This is the same location where the HDPI has been installed.)

Install the Messaging service installation files.
If you pre-downloaded the installation file, run the following command to install it:cd <directory where the pre-downloaded file is> openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi messaging install <filename>When installing pre-downloaded files, make sure you run the installer from the same directory where the installation files are. If the installer cannot find a file with the name you provided in the local directory, it will attempt to download the files again.
If you did not pre-download the installation file,
Find the most recent version of the file. Note that this command provides only a quick list of recent files; there are more complete listing options available that include installation status.openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi listThe output should look similar to:+----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+ | service | id | version | state | +----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+ | Helion Code Engine | wscatalog.2776 | 1.0.0 | available | | als | wscatalog.2765 | 2.0.0.539 | available | | als | wscatalog.2800 | 2.0.0.548 | available | | database | wscatalog.2762 | 2.0.0.32 | available | | database | wscatalog.2803 | 2.0.0.37 | available | | messaging | wscatalog.2761 | 1.0.0 | available | | messaging | wscatalog.2796 | 1.0.0.165 | available | +----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+
Find the ID number of the most recent version of the service (the highest ID number for that service).
If desired, inspect the installation files for size, version, and other detailed information.openstack hdpi show wscatalog.#### --os-cloud mycloud
Begin the download and installation:openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi messaging install wscatalog.####

Launch the Messaging Deployer VM using the HDPI.When the launch command indicates that it finished and provides the IP address for the Messaging Deployer VM, SSH into the Messaging Deployer VM and look for the /home/stack/helion directory. Once that directory has been created and populated, continue to the next step. Do not attempt to continue until the directory has been populated; this may take a few minutes after the launch command indicates that it has completed. (dev_platform_installer-devplat_installer-1.0.0)stack@hlm:~$ openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi messaging launch
This will return output similar to the following: =show the server=========================================== +--------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +--------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | OS-EXT-AZ:availability_zone | nova | | OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host | helion-cp1-comp0006-mgmt | | OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hypervisor_hostname | helion-cp1-comp0006-mgmt | | OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name | instance-00000016 | | OS-EXT-STS:power_state | 1 | | OS-EXT-STS:task_state | None | | OS-EXT-STS:vm_state | active | | OS-SRV-USG:launched_at | 2015-11-04T22:45:43.000000 | | OS-SRV-USG:terminated_at | None | | accessIPv4 | | | accessIPv6 | | | addresses | SVC=10.241.145.12 | | config_drive | | | created | 2015-11-04T22:44:29Z | | flavor | m1.medium (3) | | hostId | 8d1c5e76b6cbc4616ee9ee1ba4d66451f921ac5e4395b4996c04aaa0 | | id | 8fb9334e-ea13-4a1e-aa8c-bd20148f7a42 | | image | msgaas-1.0.0-rc5_cloud-1.0.20151029T002941Z (4b1ea7c6-24a6-4ae7-9456-e65130de51f9) | | key_name | msgaas | | name | messaging_deployer | | os-extended-volumes:volumes_attached | [] | | progress | 0 | | project_id | 02c783d40f7b4d969a9b6847c07e5df2 | | properties | | | security_groups | [{u'name': u'default'}] | | status | ACTIVE | | updated | 2015-11-04T22:45:43Z | | user_id | c241938bec504ed6ac284e432cff32df | +--------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ =done====================================================== Scripts complete. Completed launching messaging

Log in to and Initialize the Messaging Deployer VM
SSH into the Messaging Deployer VM using the IP address provided (highlighted above) after the launch command completed.
Copy the msgaas deployment model.The cp command must be used exactly as shown - including the /* on the end of the example model path. stack@messaging-deployer:~/msgaas-1.0.0-rc1$ cd ~/helion/ stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ cp -r examples/msgaas/* my_cloud/definition/ stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ cp ~/platform-pass-through.yml my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/platform-pass-through.yml
Using Git, persist the input model that you are about to deploy with. This information is required for the Pre-Install playbook, which is executed later in this installation process.stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ git add -A stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ git commit -a -m "Add MSGaaS Default Model"
Change to the default values in order to customize the deployment model. Do not skip this step or the installation playbooks may not execute as expected in your environment.# Open the cloudConfig.yml file and provide appropriate NTP/DNS server IP addresses # If you are not sure, use the IP addresses of the HP Helion OpenStack control plane nodes # The NTP and DNS servers must be reachable from your HP Helion OpenStack SVC network
stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ cd my_cloud/definition/ stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/my_cloud/definition$ ls cloudConfig.yml data stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/my_cloud/definition$ nano cloudConfig.yml # this is the file where the changes need to be made
This step is required for configuring TLS in Cue API endpoint. For production environments, TLS (Cue API public endpoint URL with SSL support (https)) is recommended. If not using TLS, for example, in a non-production proof-of-concept environment, skip this step.
Navigate to and open the network_groups.yml file for editing.stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/my_cloud/definition$ cd data stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data$ nano network_groups.yml
If an IP-based TLS certificate is used, comment out the external-name: field. For name-based TLS, provide the FQDN name in the external-name: field and copy the signed certificate to the ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/ directory.
Comment out the components: list and uncomment the tls-components: list.
Un-comment the tls-components: list.
provide the TLS certificate file name in the cert-file: field. This name will have to match the name of the cert-file placed in ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/ (e.g. msgaas-cert). The certificate file must contain both the certificate and the private key data.
Using Git, persist these changes. This information is required for the Pre-Install playbook, which is executed later in this installation process.stack@messaging-deployer:/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through$ cd ~/helion stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ git add -A # Required if you copied a new cert file stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model"

Run the Playbooks After each playbook runs, both unreachable and failed should be zero (0). This indicates success. If not, check the output for error messages, address the errors, and try running the playbook again.If more detailed output is desired, add the debug option (-vvv) or verbose debug option (-vvvv) to any ansible playbook call. (ansible-playbook)
Run the Pre-Install Playbook For the SVC network, the only valid name is "SVC". If the External Network is not named ext-net, update the value of the external_net_name variable in ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/openstack-operations/defaults/main.yml to the correct value.stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ source ~/user.osrc stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion$ cd hos/ansible/ stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-pre-install.yml
The output should look similar to the following:PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** openstack-operations | preinstall | Create service ports ---------------- 5.14s openstack-operations | lookup-keystone-ids | Lookup Project ID ---------- 2.98s openstack-operations | preinstall | Ensure SVC Network Exists ----------- 2.75s openstack-operations | preinstall | Ensure External Network Exists ------ 2.73s openstack-operations | preinstall | Create Floating IPs necessary for load-balancers --- 2.17s openstack-operations | preinstall | Identify pre-existing floating IPs --- 2.07s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Neutron Quotas ------------------ 2.07s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Cinder Quotas ------------------- 2.01s openstack-operations | preinstall | Create Virtual IPs necessary for load-balancers externally managed --- 1.81s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Nova Quotas --------------------- 1.77s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ----------------------------------------------------------------- 27.45s localhost : ok=20 changed=14 unreachable=0 failed=0
Configure the Input Model for TLS Support in Cue API (Optional).If using name-based TLS, skip this step, otherwise the deployment model customization performed previously must have included the TLS configuration step.
Navigate to and open the network_groups.yml file, capture the ip address shown in the external-ip: field. Now create and sign an IP-based TLS certificate based on this IP address.
Copy your signed certificate into ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/. Ensure the certificate name matches the name you provided in cert-file: field.
Using Git, commit the changes. stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ git add -A stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model"
Run the Config Processor Playbook stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
If you have performed a full installation previously, you must remove the Cue user and service from Keystone before running this playbook again.
SSH into the HPE Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager (deployer node), source the keystone.osrc file, and then execute these commands:openstack service delete cue openstack user delete cue Successful output should look similar to the following. PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** config-processor | run-config-processor | Run Configuration Processor over the given cloud configuration --- 2.44s git-operations | _assemble-working-directory | Assemble scratch content --- 0.76s git-operations | _persist-to-git | Prep new commit ---------------------- 0.69s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.67s config-processor | add-localhost | Add localhost group entry ------------ 0.55s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.33s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.32s config-processor | configure | Copy hosts.hf for osconfig playbooks ----- 0.28s config-processor | configure | Copy ansible hosts file for cloud deployment (verb_hosts) --- 0.28s config-processor | add-localhost | Add localhost group ------------------ 0.17s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ------------------------------------------------------------------ 7.99s localhost : ok=21 changed=14 unreachable=0 failed=0
Run the Ready Deployment Playbookstack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Successful output should look similar to the following. Ignore the TASK/msg message at the end of the output. Do not run the playbook as indicated; that playbook must be run later in the installation process.PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** git-operations | _assemble-working-directory | Assemble scratch content --- 0.73s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.54s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.49s git-operations | _promote-from-staging | Update branches ---------------- 0.41s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.30s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.27s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.26s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.25s config-processor | configure | Copy ansible hosts file for cloud deployment (verb_hosts) --- 0.24s config-processor | configure | Copy hosts.hf for osconfig playbooks ----- 0.22s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ------------------------------------------------------------------ 5.96s localhost : ok=20 changed=11 unreachable=0 failed=0
TASK: [git-operations | ready-deployment-tree-help | Tell the user what to expect] *** ok: [localhost] => { "msg": "The directory /home/stack/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible contains a prepared ansible tree ready to run your deployment. You should cd into that directory and run: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml" }
Run the Boot Infrastructure Playbook This step takes approximately 5 minutes. Once this is complete, all in-cloud infrastructure (VMs, Networks, Routers, Floating IPs, ports, security groups, etc) will have been created. stack@messaging-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible stack@messaging-deployer:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.yml
Successful output should look similar to the following:PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** openstack-operations | create_instance | Create controlplane instance - 227.92s openstack-operations | create_instance | Give cloud-init time to fetch SSH keys -- 60.07s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create tcp/icmp security groups rules -- 34.59s openstack-operations | create_instance | Extract port-id --------------- 19.89s openstack-operations | create_instance | Wait for SSH to become active -- 17.46s openstack-operations | create_port | Update ports to include appropriate security group(s) -- 17.24s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create security groups -- 16.18s openstack-operations | create_port | Associate VIP to instance ports --- 14.85s openstack-operations | create_port | Create instance ports ------------- 13.97s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create other security groups rules (e.g. 112 protcol) --- 9.33s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ---------------------------------------------------------------- 471.97s localhost : ok=35 changed=19 unreachable=0 failed=0
Run the Site Playbook Unlike all the previous ansible plays, the inventory file supplied to this play is hosts/verb_hosts and not hosts/localhostThis step takes approximately 10 to 15 minutes. stack@messaging-deployer:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml Successful output should look similar to the following: If this playbook does not run successfully, run it again before trying any more advanced troubleshooting.PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** FND-MDB | start | Start MySQL ------------------------------------------ 85.62s FND-MDB | install | Install MDB packages ------------------------------- 75.00s rabbitmq | install | Install rabbitmq application ---------------------- 20.34s rabbitmq | install | Install rabbitmq application ---------------------- 20.28s rabbitmq | install | Install rabbitmq application ---------------------- 19.75s DES-PDN | install | Install Power DNS packages ------------------------- 17.48s FND-MDB | configure | Bootstrap MDB Master ----------------------------- 11.26s logging-producer | configure | Setup config files for services that have subscribed for logging -- 10.87s logging-producer | configure | Include default log files for centralized logging --- 9.83s Install keepalived package ---------------------------------------------- 9.21s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ---------------------------------------------------------------- 611.95s msgaas-msgaas-ccp-c1-m1-mgmt : ok=377 changed=190 unreachable=0 failed=0 msgaas-msgaas-ccp-c1-m2-mgmt : ok=381 changed=194 unreachable=0 failed=0 msgaas-msgaas-ccp-c1-m3-mgmt : ok=382 changed=196 unreachable=0 failed=0 localhost : ok=34 changed=15 unreachable=0 failed=0

section.title: Finding the IP address for nodes in a name-based installation
section.p: If you used name-based TLS in step 5.f.1, you can find the IP address of the service endpoint by doing one of the following:

ol.li: Connect to the application lifecycle (deployer) node

Execute the following command to get the service endpoint address from the Hosts file: cat /etc/hosts This will produce output similar to the following:
# Cloud: entry-scale-kvm-ceph
# Localhost Information 127.0.0.1 localhost
# # Network Group: EXTERNAL-API # # Network: EXTERNAL-API-NET 10.241.151.2 helion-cp1-c1-m1-extapi 10.241.151.3 helion-cp1-c1-m2-extapi 10.241.151.4 helion-cp1-c1-m3-extapi

body.section:
Verifying the Installation
Set endpoint type to internal (Cannot access public endpoint from messaging deployer) API.export OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE=internalURL export OS_INTERFACE=internal
List all clusters. Since you have not yet created any clusters, this list of clusters will be empty, but it should execute without returning any error messages. stack@messaging-deployer:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ /opt/stack/service/cueclient/venv/bin/openstack message-broker cluster list If you have configured TLS, make sure that the Cue public endpoint begins with https and not just http:openstack catalog list
